Docs.summary: Represents a set of properties for a message. This class cannot be inherited.

remarks.format:
## Remarks As a message passes through the channel infrastructure, it passes through a number of logically separate processing entities. For instance, a message that is part of a reliable messaging stream can potentially pass through a <xref:System.ServiceModel.Channels.MessageEncoder>, a transport-level channel provider, the reliable-messaging channel provider, the streaming channel provider or any channel extensions. Sometimes these intermediaries annotate the message with the results of that processing by using the <xref:System.ServiceModel.Channels.MessageProperties> class. A <xref:System.ServiceModel.Channels.MessageProperties> instance is an annotation on a message and is stored as a set of name-to-object mappings in the <xref:System.ServiceModel.Channels.Message.Properties%2A> property of a <xref:System.ServiceModel.Channels.Message> instance.
> [!NOTE] > The message properties should be cleared out when the user gets the following error: > > **The server committed a protocol violation. Section=ResponseBody Detail=Response chunk format is invalid**

Docs.summary: Releases all resources used by the class.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Call <xref:System.ServiceModel.Channels.MessageProperties.Dispose%2A> when you are finished using the <xref:System.ServiceModel.Channels.MessageProperties>. The <xref:System.ServiceModel.Channels.MessageProperties.Dispose%2A> method leaves the <xref:System.ServiceModel.Channels.MessageProperties> in an unusable state. After calling <xref:System.ServiceModel.Channels.MessageProperties.Dispose%2A>, you must release all references to the <xref:System.ServiceModel.Channels.MessageProperties> so the garbage collector can reclaim the memory that the <xref:System.ServiceModel.Channels.MessageProperties> occupied.
> [!NOTE] > Always call <xref:System.ServiceModel.Channels.MessageProperties.Dispose%2A> before you release your last reference to the <xref:System.ServiceModel.Channels.MessageProperties>. Otherwise, the resources it is using are not freed until the garbage collector calls the <xref:System.ServiceModel.Channels.MessageProperties> object's `Finalize` method.

MemberSignature.Value: public: property System::ServiceModel::Security::SecurityMessageProperty ^ Security { System::ServiceModel::Security::SecurityMessageProperty ^ get(); void set(System::ServiceModel::Security::SecurityMessageProperty ^ value); };

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the security-related property of a message.

remarks.format: ## Remarks HTTP client authentication results are translated into an instance of <xref:System.ServiceModel.Security.Tokens.ServiceModelSecurityTokenTypes.SecurityContext%2A>, which is attached to the message using a <xref:System.ServiceModel.Security.SecurityMessageProperty>. This property can be used by higher layers to implement arbitrary authorization logic.

MemberSignature.Value: public: property Uri ^ Via { Uri ^ get(); void set(Uri ^ value); };
member this.Via : Uri with get, set

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the transport address that is used to send messages.
Docs.value: A URI that contains the transport address that is used to send messages.

remarks.format: ## Remarks The transport channel owns the <xref:System.ServiceModel.Channels.MessageProperties.Via%2A> property and it overwrites whatever value you set for the message headers. You do have one opportunity to set the channel's `Via`, which is during the creation of the channel from the channel factory, for example, with <xref:System.ServiceModel.ChannelFactory%601.CreateChannel%28System.ServiceModel.EndpointAddress%2CSystem.Uri%29>.
